To address this, fuzzers employ distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest seed subset triggering the same instrumentation coverage as the full corpus. Minimizing seed count and cumulative size is widely believed to improve fuzzing efficiency—a claim we systematically investigate. We present findings from 34+ CPU-years of fuzzing with five distillation methods to evaluate their bug-finding impact in real-world software.

original: In this paper we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be divided into several groups in each of which the agents have similar (isomorphic) state transition structures, and thus can be relabeled into the same template. Based on the template a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents is designed for the case of partial observation. The scalable supervisor under partial observation does not need to be recomputed regardless of how many agents are added to or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.
polished: "In this paper, we examine multi-agent discrete-event systems under partial observation. The agents can be grouped such that each group shares isomorphic state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into a common template. Using this template, we design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost remain unaffected by the number of agents. This supervisor, under partial observation, requires no recomputation even as agents are added or removed. We extend prior results by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the least restrictive scalable supervisor at the template level. An example demonstrates the proposed synthesis method.

original: Electric network frequency (enf) fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for enf estimation is introduced with temporal windowing based on the filter-bank capon spectral estimator. A type of gohberg-semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is used due to the toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach uses, for the first time in the field of enf, a temporal window, not necessarily the rectangular one, at the stage preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are employed for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in enf estimation, when a short time window of $1$ second is employed in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields highly accurate results with respect to both time complexity and accuracy.
polished: Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient ENF estimation method is proposed, utilizing temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. A Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is employed, leveraging its Toeplitz structure. Additionally, this approach introduces, for the first time in ENF analysis, a non-rectangular temporal window prior to spectral estimation. Krylov matrices enable fast matrix inversion. The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in ENF estimation for 1-second power recordings. In speech recordings, it achieves high accuracy with improved time complexity.

original: The direpack package aims to establish a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the python universe as a single, consistent package. The dimension reduction methods included resort into three categories: projection pursuit based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust m estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are provided as well, ranging from classical principal component regression up to sparse partial robust m regression. The package also contains a set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Finally, direpack has been written consistent with the scikit-learn api, such that the estimators can flawlessly be included into (statistical and/or machine) learning pipelines in that framework.
polished: The direpack package introduces a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques to the Python ecosystem as a unified and consistent toolkit. The included methods fall into three categories: projection pursuit, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators. Additionally, regularized regression estimators based on reduced dimensions are provided, spanning from principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package also offers classical and robust preprocessing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, along with dedicated plotting and cross-validation tools. Designed to align with the scikit-learn API, direpack seamlessly integrates into statistical and machine learning pipelines within that framework.

original: The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for the high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we studied the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. The fluorescence reduction was observed with high power laser excitation. It increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission, and changed the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We used a differential excitation protocol to extract the high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved approximate 1.6 times in comparison with the confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method can be used for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with the defects in solids.
polished: The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely used for high-resolution optical imaging. Here, we investigated the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect in nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond. Fluorescence reduction was observed under high-power laser excitation, enhancing emission nonlinearity and altering the spatial frequency distribution of the image. A differential excitation protocol extracted high spatial frequency information. By modulating the laser power, imaging resolution improved by approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Given the experimental simplicity and straightforward data processing, we anticipate this method will enhance spatial resolution for sensing and biological labeling with solid-state defects.

original: When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the usual approach of employing individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer produces asymptotically unbiased inference. We construct a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We contrast our approach with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration to reveal that only the bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data example for a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a capstone for recent developmental efforts that combine traditional survey estimation approaches with the bayesian modeling paradigm and provides a bridge across the two rich but disparate sub-fields.
polished: When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, standard methods that use individual survey weights (inversely proportional to inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood fail to provide asymptotically unbiased inference. We propose a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution, ensuring unbiased hyperparameter estimation. Our approach outperforms frequentist methods relying on numerical integration, as only the Bayesian method achieves both design-unbiased estimation and population-consistent inference. Simulations and a business establishment survey demonstrate our method's versatility across models and sampling designs. This work culminates recent efforts integrating survey estimation with Bayesian modeling, bridging two distinct yet rich sub-fields.

original: Low-symmetry 2d materials---such as res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-iv monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, among others---have more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely new properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also take place due to low symmetry. The "beyond graphene: low-symmetry and anisotropic 2d materials" special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.
polished: Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS₂ and ReSe₂ monolayers, black phosphorus, group-IV monochalcogenides, and borophene—exhibit more intricate atomic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. Their reduced symmetries lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, along with novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, strong nonlinear optical effects, photogalvanic responses, and superconductivity. Unique electronic topologies, nonlinear elasticity, and structural phase transitions also arise from low symmetry. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic highlights recent experimental and theoretical advances in these emerging materials.

original: Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups was studied using the kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, in contrast to low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be presented by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These main processes replace each other in a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also made it possible to distinguish two processes of orientational relaxation: the first is due to rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with motion of the main chain segments.
polished: Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, results revealed that in a mesogenic polymer—unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens—the relaxation of electric birefringence above the nematic-isotropic transition temperature can be described by multiple exponential processes, with two dominant contributions. These primary processes alternate within a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy further identified two orientational relaxation mechanisms: one arising from side-group rotation and the other linked to main-chain segment motion.

original: Deep hashing methods have shown great retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. How to optimize discrete hash bits is always the focus in deep hashing methods. A common strategy in these methods is to adopt an activation function, e.g. $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm may make more and more hash bits stuck into the wrong saturated area of the activation functions and never escaped. We call this problem "dead bits problem~(dbp)". Besides, the existing quantization loss will aggravate dbp as well. In this paper, we propose a simple but effective gradient amplifier which acts before activation functions to alleviate dbp.
polished: Deep hashing methods have demonstrated strong retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a key focus in these methods. A common strategy is to use activation functions like $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, minimizing quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this approach can trap hash bits in the wrong saturated regions of activation functions, preventing recovery. We term this issue the "dead bits problem (dbp)." Additionally, existing quantization loss worsens dbp. To address this, we propose a simple yet effective gradient amplifier applied before activation functions to mitigate dbp.

original: We study the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero su(2) triplet scalar whose existence is motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We consider both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the standard model higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the lhc and by dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass less than $230\ \mathrm{gev}$ is excluded at $95\%$ confidence level.
polished: We examine the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We explore scenarios where the triplet is either stable (contributing to dark matter) or decays via Higgs mixing. The stable case is constrained by LHC disappearing-track searches and direct detection experiments, while the decaying case faces limits from multilepton collider searches. A two-step phase transition with a stable triplet and negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection, whereas an unstable triplet below $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is excluded at $95\%$ confidence.

original: This paper shows that the eccentric debris rings seen around the stars fomalhaut and hd 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario (sometimes referred to as "pericenter glow"). The standard scenario posits an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity is increased to $e_f$ after the gas disc has dispersed by secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. In a minor modification of this scenario, narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. However, a primordial eccentricity could alternatively be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.
polished: This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than predicted by the standard eccentric planet perturbation model (often termed "pericenter glow"). According to this model, an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis \(a\) gains an eccentricity \(e_f\) via secular perturbations from an eccentric planet after gas disc dispersal, producing a belt of width \(2ae_f\). A slight modification suggests narrower belts could form if planetesimals are initially eccentric, possibly due to earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary phase. Alternatively, primordial eccentricity might arise from disc instabilities, independent of planets.

original: An electron is usually considered to have only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more, for its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? in one dimension (1d), the physics of interacting electrons is captured well at low energies by the tomonaga-luttinger-liquid (tll) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1d gated-wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, together with the emergence of three additional 1d 'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1d inter-subband screening by over 45%.
polished: An electron is typically considered to possess only one form of kinetic energy, but could it exhibit additional types due to its spin, charge, or interactions with other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is well described at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model, yet experimental observations beyond this linear regime remain scarce. Here, we present measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using tunneling spectroscopy. We identify two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, linked to spin and charge excitations, alongside the appearance of three additional 1D "replica" modes that intensify as wire length decreases. The effective interaction strength is tuned by varying 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

original: $context$. The assembly history experienced by the milky way is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the $gaia$ mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. $aims$. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the milky way has experienced. $methods$. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by $gaia$ for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin we analysed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. $results$. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.
polished: $context$. The Milky Way's assembly history is now being revealed through data from the $Gaia$ mission. The galaxy's globular cluster system likely followed an equally complex formation path. $aims$. To constrain this path, we investigate the connection between globular clusters and the Milky Way's known merger events. $methods$. We combine $Gaia$'s kinematic data for nearly all galactic clusters with the largest available sample of cluster ages, corrected for systematic errors. To identify clusters of common origin, we analyze their dynamical properties, focusing on integrals of motion. $results$. We find that roughly 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

original: The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article illustrates intrinsic, an r package that implements novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. In detail, the methods included in this package are the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To allow these novel estimators to be easily accessible, the package contains a few high-level, intuitive functions that rely on a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models that fall into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category contains the two-nn and gride models. The functions dedicated to these two methods carry out inference under both the frequentist and bayesian frameworks. In the second category we find hidalgo, a bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient gibbs sampler is implemented.
polished: The estimation of a dataset's intrinsic dimension is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces *intrinsic*, an R package that implements state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators for intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the package includes the TWO-NN, Gride, and Hidalgo models. To ensure accessibility, *intrinsic* provides high-level, intuitive functions built on efficient low-level routines. The package features two categories of estimators: homogeneous and heterogeneous. The first includes TWO-NN and Gride, with functions supporting both frequentist and Bayesian inference. The second category comprises Hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

original: Spintronic nanodevices have ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale that promises to enable spintronic reservoir computing (rc) system. Here two physical rc systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (msm) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (stnos) were proposed and modeled to process image classification task and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of msm and stno with current pulses stimulation, the handwritten digits recognition task domesticates that an rc system using one single msm has the outstanding performance on image classification. In addition, the complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be well solved by a physical rc system consisted of 24 stnos confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and narma10 tasks.
polished: Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, enabling spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Here, two physical RC systems—one based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and another using 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs)—were modeled for image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Micromagnetic simulations of MSM and STNO responses to current pulses demonstrate that an RC system with a single MSM achieves outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition. Furthermore, a physical RC system comprising 24 STNOs effectively solves complex nonlinear dynamic problems, as validated by second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

original: Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms ranging from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we identify a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items reporting a given signal, the higher the share of the overall traffic they collectively attract. This few-get-richer effect emerges in settings where there are few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on their popularity. We demonstrate analytically that the few-get-richer effect emerges when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for the classes of items. Using simulations, we analyze how the strength of the effect changes with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also test our predictions experimentally in an online experiment with human participants. Our findings have important implications to understand the spread of misinformation.
polished: Ranking algorithms play a vital role in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we uncover an unexpected consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items sharing a signal, the greater their collective share of traffic. This few-get-richer effect arises when distinct item classes are limited (e.g., left-leaning vs. right-leaning news sources) and rankings depend on popularity. We analytically show this effect occurs when users favor top-ranked items and exhibit diverse class preferences. Through simulations, we examine how the effect's intensity varies with contextual and behavioral assumptions. We also validate our predictions experimentally in an online study. These findings offer critical insights into misinformation spread.

original: Weight pruning has been widely acknowledged as a straightforward and effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (dnn), thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most of the pruning techniques are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity which lead to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To solve the problem, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity that comprises pattern and connectivity sparsity, and becoming both highly accurate and hardware friendly. With carefully designed patterns, the proposed pruning unprecedentedly and consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and better feature extraction ability on different dnn structures and datasets, and our pattern-aware pruning framework also achieves pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning and weight training simultaneously. Our approach on the new pattern-based sparsity naturally fits into compiler optimization for highly efficient dnn execution on mobile platforms.
polished: Weight pruning is widely recognized as a simple yet effective method to reduce redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), enabling acceleration across platforms. However, most pruning techniques compromise between accuracy and regularity, often degrading inference accuracy and limiting on-device acceleration. To address this, we introduce pattern-based sparsity—a novel dimension combining pattern and connectivity sparsity—delivering high accuracy and hardware efficiency. By leveraging carefully designed patterns, our pruning method consistently enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction across diverse DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our framework integrates pattern library extraction, selection, pruning, and weight training seamlessly. This approach naturally aligns with compiler optimizations, ensuring efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

original: Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs considerably from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events that have different effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in less bias. We study this phenomenon in simulation studies. We study the effect of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that makes use of the increase in mrm following the 1990 clean air act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95\% confidence interval that contains substantial adverse effects along with no effect and small beneficial effects.
polished: Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs significantly from a treated group risks bias due to historical events affecting the groups differently. Creating a more closely matched control group by selecting a subset of the overall controls may reduce bias. We examine this phenomenon through simulations. We analyze the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences approach, leveraging the rise in MRM after the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For our analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we developed a better-matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval spanning substantial adverse effects, no effect, and minor beneficial effects.

original: When constructing models to summarize clinical data to be used for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their capacity to reproduce the data. This can be done by means of visual predictive checks (vpc), which consist of (1) several reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is straightforward to apply, in general. Here we consider the application of the method to time to event data and consider the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.
polished: When building models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is essential to assess their ability to reproduce the data. This can be achieved through visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve: (1) simulating multiple replicates of the original study using the model, (2) computing key estimates for each simulated dataset, and (3) comparing their distribution with the original estimate. This approach is a versatile and generally straightforward method. Here, we apply it to time-to-event data and examine the specific case where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated post-event.

original: Novel concepts, perspectives and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are shown. We discuss how similar protocols, relying both on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can allow to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies.
polished: Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential schemes are presented. We explore how similar protocols, combining repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, enable: (i) confining and protecting quantum dynamics from decoherence in line with Zeno physics. (ii) analytically predicting the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state via stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstructing environmental noise spectral density by orthogonalizing filter functions in the frequency domain for quantum-sensor design. These advancements will improve our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, driving progress in quantum science and technology.

original: "to do two things at once is to do neither." it's a great smackdown of multitasking, isn't it, often attributed to the roman writer publilius syrus, although you know how these things are, he probably never said it. polished: To do two things at once is to do neither." This sharp critique of multitasking is often credited to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, though he likely never said it. What intrigues me is its validity. It clearly holds for emailing at dinner, texting while driving, or live-tweeting a TED Talk. Yet I’d argue that for certain tasks, doing two—or even four—things at once is ideal. Consider Albert Einstein, who published four groundbreaking papers in 1905.

original: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.so what do we call this? i think we call it restorative seafood. polished: Sustainability defines the what, where, and how of what is caught. The who and why matter most to me. I want to know the people behind my meals, how I affect them, and how they affect me. I want to understand why they fish and how they depend on the water's bounty for their livelihood. Grasping this shifts our view of seafood from a commodity to a chance to heal our ecosystem. It lets us appreciate the seafood we’re lucky to enjoy. So what do we call this? I call it restorative seafood. While sustainability is about enduring, restorative means replenishing and progressing.

polished: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists awaiting critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers to save their lives. We begin in 1964. Bob Dylan, 23, is at the peak of his career. Hailed as the voice of a generation, he produces timeless songs at an astonishing pace. Yet a small group claims he steals others' work.  

In 2004, Brian Burton, aka Danger Mouse, blends The Beatles' *White Album* with Jay-Z's *The Black Album*, creating *The Grey Album*. It quickly goes viral, but The Beatles' label issues cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition." Today, *The Grey Album* stands as a remix.

polished: I have two questions for you. First: whose shoulders do you stand on? And second: what do you stand for? These are the questions I open my poetry workshops with because poetry can sometimes feel like a relic—an art form for old white men who seemed destined to be elderly, like Benjamin Button. I ask my students these questions, then share my own answers in three lines: I am the daughter of Black writers, descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. These words become my mantra before every poetry performance—I was even reciting them earlier, making faces in the corner.

original: On october 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the soviet union launched sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the u.s. And u.s.s.r. That would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was actually not the first piece of human technology to enter space. That superlative goes to the v-2 rocket used by germany in missile attacks against allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of world war ii. polished: On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the first artificial satellite, into space. This small metal sphere, less than two feet wide, ignited an 18-year space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R., reshaping history. However, Sputnik wasn’t humanity’s initial venture beyond Earth. That distinction belongs to Germany’s V-2 rocket, deployed in WWII’s final years. Though ineffective, postwar, both superpowers seized the technology—and its creators—for their own ambitions.

original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. polished: Menstruation—a simple word describing a natural biological process—is burdened by centuries of stigma, reduced to a topic many whisper about. But why? Right now, over 800 million women worldwide are menstruating. None of us would exist without it, yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject. From my experience and that of countless women, I can say it’s exhausting. Exhausting to hide a pad in a brown paper bag, stuff it into your pocket mid-class, and rush discreetly to the washroom. Exhausting to sit through lessons or meetings, pretending everything’s fine while enduring intense cramps.

original: In 1903, the president of the united states took a three-day camping trip in california’s yosemite valley. President theodore roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist john muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but muir had invited him there for more than just camping: yosemite was in danger.though yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk for overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use— two goals that were much easier said than done.the battle over yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the sierra nevada foothills.
polished: In 1903, the president of the United States embarked on a three-day camping trip in California’s Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt slept among towering sequoias, weathered a snowstorm, and shared campfire conversations with his host, conservationist John Muir. Though Roosevelt adored the outdoors, Muir’s invitation served a greater purpose: Yosemite was under threat. Despite gaining protected status in 1864, the valley faced overdevelopment by 1903. It stood at the center of a decades-long struggle to balance preservation and public access—goals far harder to achieve than to declare. The conflict over Yosemite traces back to the 1849 Gold Rush, when miners flooded the Sierra Nevada foothills.

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished: Imagine if you could connect your mind to a machine offering endless pleasure for life. If given the choice, would you embrace such an existence? That’s the question philosopher Robert Nozick explored in his thought experiment, the Experience Machine. It challenges us to envision a world where scientists create a device simulating reality—delivering only joy and no suffering. The catch? You must abandon reality permanently, though the difference would be imperceptible. Your experiences would mirror real life, but its natural highs and lows would vanish, replaced by ceaseless euphoria. Sounds perfect, doesn’t it?

original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished: Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon operates in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in soil, oceans, the atmosphere, and deep underground rocks. When plants and organisms die, much of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants absorb it. Over millions of years, some carbon from ancient trees and marine life forms rocks or fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas. Volcanic eruptions release carbon trapped in rock, while human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, unleash prehistoric carbon. Today, humans emit roughly 60 times more carbon annually than all volcanoes combined.

polished: Even nature's most repulsive creatures hold vital secrets, but who would welcome a swarm of cockroaches? Yet one key distinction between natural and human technologies lies in robustness. Robust systems remain stable in complex, unfamiliar environments. Astonishingly, cockroaches can self-stabilize while running over rough terrain. When equipped with a jet pack or subjected to disturbances like earthquakes, their finely tuned legs enable self-stabilization without brainpower. They traverse complex terrain like grass effortlessly, maintaining stability. We observed a novel behavior: their body shape allows them to roll sideways automatically to navigate artificial grass patches. Robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure—a fascinating discovery.

These are grim economic times, fellow TEDsters—grim indeed. To lift your spirits, let me share one of the great, albeit lesser-known, commercial success stories of the past two decades. In its own peculiar way, it rivals the achievements of Microsoft or Google. This industry has weathered the current recession with remarkable ease: organized crime.  

Now, organized crime is nothing new, you might say—and you’d be right. But over the last 20 years, it has expanded unprecedentedly, now accounting for roughly 15% of global GDP. I call it the "global shadow economy," or McMafia for short. So, what fueled this explosive growth in cross-border crime?
